unnormalised: Someone asked me why we use "Ji" after names in India. Well, "Ji" is like a super common honorific, right? Think of it as similar to "Sir" or "Madam," but way more versatile. You can use it for pretty much anyone you respect or want to show a little politeness to. Like, you’d call your elder brother "Bhai Ji" or your teacher "Madam Ji". It's especially used when you don't know someone's name or want to be extra respectful. So, if you're asking a shopkeeper for the price of something, you'd say "Kitne ka hai Ji?"

unnormalised: It's not just for formal situations, either. I often hear my mom calling the vegetable vendor "Sharma Ji," even though they've known each other for ages. It's more of a habit and a sign of warmth. My grandpa insists we call the auto-rickshaw driver "Uncle Ji," even if he looks younger than me! So, it can vary a bit from family to family and region to region. Don't be surprised if someone uses "Ji" even with people they are familiar with.

unnormalised: Basically, "Ji" is a flexible way to add a touch of respect and familiarity in everyday conversation. It's a cultural thing, and you'll hear it everywhere, from bustling markets to fancy restaurants. It’s a little difficult to explain, but trust me you will pick it up by spending some time in India. You will see that "Ji" is not just a word but a part of our culture, like how "Namaste Ji" is a common greeting. It makes conversations sound warmer and more polite, doesn't it?
